Elementary Steps Energies Ea ΔG CO* →CHO* 8.77 16.71 CHO* →CH2O* 6.02 -11.80 CH2O* →CH3O* – -35.55 CH3O* →CH3 * +O* 38.08 9.94 CH3 * +CHO* →CH3CHO* – -31.45 CH3CHO* →CH3CH2O* 20.54 -3.7 CH3CH2O* →CH3CH2OH* 3.88 -18.02 Insight into the Mechanism of Reverse Water-gas Shift Reaction and Ethanol Formation Catalyzed by Mo6S8-TM Clusters Xiaoli Zheng Ling Guo ⁎ Wenli Li Zhaoru Cao Naying Liu Qian Zhang Minmin Xing Yayin Shi Juan Guo School of Chemistry and Material Science, Modern College of Arts and Sciences, Shanxi Normal University, Linfen 041004, China School of Chemistry and Material Science Modern College of Arts and Sciences Shanxi Normal University Linfen 041004 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Potential energy surfaces for the carboxyl mechanism of RWGS reaction promoted by Mo6S8-Pd. We studied the mechanism of the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS; CO2 +H2 →CO+H2O) and ethanol formation catalyzed by Mo6S8-TM (TM=Pd, Pt, Ag) clusters using density-functional theory (DFT) calculations. We considered five different reaction pathways relevant to the RWGS reaction as follows: the redox mechanism, the carboxyl mechanism, the formate mechanism, the formic acid mechanism, and the formyl mechanism. We carried out the energetic span model (ESM) to explore the kinetic behavior of the five catalytic cycles. Reaction Gibbs free energies and activation energies for all pathways were determined for each transition metal. Our results indicated that the most desirable mechanism is the carboxyl mechanism. Among the three catalysts clusters, the Mo6S8-Pd cluster shows the most favorable catalytic properties. Then, we explored the ethanol synthesis starting with CO and H2 on the Mo6S8-Pd cluster. Calculations showed that the ethanol formation via *CHO, *CH2O, *CH3O, *CH3, CH3CHO*, CH3CH2O*, and the Mo6S8-Pd cluster is beneficial to synthesis of ethanol. Keywords Mo6S8-TM clusters RWGS reaction Ethanol formation Reaction mechanism TOF 1 Introduction The combustion of fossil fuels, a major source of energy in the present-day economy, releases a staggering amount of CO2 into the atmosphere [1] leading to adverse effects on climate and the environment. Rather than treat CO2 as a waste product, it can also be viewed and utilized as a valuable feedstock for liquid fuels, which could solve a number of interconnected and challenging problems associated with finite conventional petroleum resources, and concerns for global climate change. One widely explored method is to combine the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) process with the Fischer–Tropsch (FT) process to produce liquid fuels using CO2 as a feedstock [2]. The RWGS is the step of reduction of CO2 using H2 and it can endothermic with a standard heat of reaction as 41.27kJmol−1. The CO produced in the RWGS reaction can then be upgraded to “drop-in” transportation fuels and chemicals through mature technologies such as methanol synthesis, ethanol synthesis, and Fischer–Tropsch synthesis [3]. Both of these downstream processing options are exothermic, RWGS reaction is the only energy intensive reaction involved in catalytic reduction of CO2 to useful fuels and chemicals. Thus, RWGS reaction is acknowledged as a very promising process. The RWGS reaction is thermodynamically viable [4], but requires the use of catalysts capable of facilitating the processes [5–7]. Thus, efforts must be put forth to develop active catalysts to overcome the slow kinetics and ensure CO is produced at the maximum allowable yield. Several transition metals, such as Ni, Ru, Rh, Pd, Pt, Cu, Ag, Au and bimetallic alloys, have been used as active catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation, including both RWGS and CO2 methanation reactions [8–13]. Osaki et al. [14] have studied the catalytic of RWGS on MoS2, WS2, Co/Al2O3, Fe/Al2O3, and they found the catalytic activity of MoS2,WS2 is lower than Co/Al2O3¡¢Fe/Al2O3, while the RWGS selectivity of MoS2,WS2 is close to 100%. Chevrel phases (CPs) have been intensively studied in the last three decades as superconductors, catalysts, thermoelectric materials, and cathodes in Li batteries [15–20]. Mo6S8 unit is optimally bonded in this size range and this supports the prominent existence of Mo6S8 clusters in a large number of CPs compounds [21]. In the cubic structure of Mo6S8, Mo atoms are at the face-centered positions, and for each Mo, the lobes of one of the t2g 4d orbitals point toward S atoms, leading to the p-d hybridization. The lobes of the other two t2g 4d orbitals point toward neighboring Mo atoms and have strong d-d hybridization, while eg states hybridize weakly. In summary, we have shown that an octahedral Mo6S8 cluster has high stability compared with other polyhedral forms. The Mo6S8 cluster has a lower S/Mo ratio compared to MoS2, which lead to the number of low-coordinated Mo sites to participate in the chemistry reaction is increasing [22]. Hence, Mo6S8 cluster is expected to be more reactive than MoS2. Bimetallic metal complex have been used in Mo6S8-based catalysts for RWGS and methanol synthesis reactions. For instance, Cao et al. [23] have studied the RWGS catalyzed by Rh-Mo6S8 cluster. Liu et al. [24] found that the Mo6S8 can catalyst methanol synthesis through RWGS reaction and HOCO intermediate. Then, they investigated methanol synthesis catalyzed by modified model Mo6S8 Cluster [25], finding that modified model Mo6S8 Cluster could affect the catalytic behavior for methanol synthesis compared to Mo6S8. What's more, Mihet et al. [26] found that promotion by Pt and Pd of Ni/γ-Al2O3 resulted in enhanced CO2 conversion in the 180-270°C domain. Pt-based catalysts are active and selective for RWGS, because they have high hydrogenation activity. For example, the Pt–Co bimetallics catalysts compared with the pure Co catalyst, the addition of Pt aids the reduction of Co, shifting the selectivity primarily toward CO. thus Pt–Co bimetallics showing higher CO production than their parent metals [27]. Qing Yu et al. [28] have found the existence of superfine Ag nanoparticles in Zn nanoplate electrodes greatly improved the selectivity and activity in the reduction of CO2 to CO. And Paskach et al. [29] have synthesized the PtMo6S8 from PtMoS in the range of 400–800°C. So it indicated that such derivatives containing Pd, Ag can also be synthesized by related chemistry. To the best of our knowledge, the exact reaction mechanism of the RWGS reaction for the Mo6S8-TM (TM=Pd, Pt, Ag) clusters have not been clearly understood yet. To clarify this unusual behavior, we studied the mechanism of the RWGS reaction catalyzed by Mo6S8-TM (TM=Pd, Pt, Ag) clusters using density-functional theory (DFT) calculations to investigate the best catalysts of the RWGS reaction. Our results indicated that the most desirable mechanism is the carboxyl mechanism. Among the three catalysts clusters, the Mo6S8-Pd cluster shows the most favorable catalytic properties, owing to the lower energetic span values (δE) and the highest TOFs. Then, we explored the ethanol synthesis starting with CO and H2 on the Mo6S8-Pd cluster. Calculations showed that the ethanol formation via *CO, *CHO, *CH2O, *CH3O, *CH3, CH3CHO*, CH3CH2O*, C2H5OH*. The key step of these processes is *CHO insertion into *CH3, and the rate-determining is the *CH3O dissociate to *CH3 and O*. The Mo6S8-Pd cluster is beneficial to ethanol synthesis. We hope that our results would stimulate experimental work to find Mo6S8Pd cluster. 2 Methods All DFT calculations presented in this work are performed with the program package Gaussian 09 program [30] implemented with PBE level. H, C, O and S atoms were described using the standard 6-31G (d, p) basis set. Considering the strong relativistic effect of Mo and TM (TM=Pd, Pt, and Ag), the LANL2DZ pseudopotential is adopted for the valence electrons, and its core electrons are represented by the LANL2DZ effective core potential (ECP) [52]. This method of many systems has been proven that it is very valid for many systems [61]. In order to obtain the catalytic performance of Mo6S8-TM, the transition states (TS) on different surfaces are searched with the complete LST/QST method [31]. This method begins by performing a liner synchronous tranit (LST)/optimization calculation. The TS approximation obtained is used to perform quadratic synchronous transit (QST) maximization. The nature (minima or first-order saddle points) of each optimized structure was identified by the subsequent frequency calculations that also provided thermal correction to Gibbs free energy. For the reaction pathways, intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) [62,63] calculations were performed to verify that each saddle point links two desired minima. The calculated bond lengths of H2, O2, CO and CO2 at PBE/6-31G (d, p) level are 0.75, 1.23, 1.15 and 1.18Å, and their binding energy values are 4.26, 5.09, 11.48 and 5.90eV, respectively. The corresponding experimental values [32] are 0.73, 1.21, 1.14, 1.16Å, 4.48, 5.12, 11.23 and 5.50eV. This shows the reliability of the basis set and functional used in our calculations. The accuracy and reliability of chosen functional and ECP for describing Mo6S8-TM have been confirmed by the calculation of Mo2 and S2 dimmers. The results are summarized in Table S1. As illustrated in Table S1, our results are in good agreement with previous experimental data [48,64,65]. In this study, reaction Gibbs free energies and activation energies for all pathways were determined for each transition metal. In order to take into consideration the effect of temperature, free energy change (△G) can be determined by ΔG = ΔE 0 + ΔG 0(T)+ RTln(pCO · pH 2 O/pCO 2 · pH 2), where △E0 is the standard energy change at 0K, and △G0(T) is the temperature correction for free energy change from 0K to T K. Some group reported that the RWGS reaction usually occur at 100-500°C [59,60], but some theoretical studies were discussed at room temperature [47]. We calculated the RWGS reactions at 25°C, 100°C, 200°C, 300°C, 400°C, 500°C. With the increase of temperature, the energy of the intermediate and transition state increases gradually. But their free energy barrier (Ea ) and the reaction energy (△G) changes little, and can be assumed to be unchanged (the effect of temperature on Mo6S8-Pd showed in Table S4, S5). Thus, in this work we discussed at room temperature. What's more, we also calculate TOF (turnover frequency) values of different mechanisms to analyze efficiency of catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Mechanism of RWGS Reaction from CO2 and H2 on Mo6S8-TM clusters Currently, in spite of an increasingly large number of studies [33–40], debates still exist on the reaction mechanism and elementary steps involved in the RWGS reaction routes. Especially, three different mechanisms have been proposed for the conversion of CO2 to CO via a RWGS pathway on metal catalysts, characterized by the following key steps [41]: CO2 →CO+O (A); CO2 +H→COOH (B); CO2 +H→HCOO (C). However, theoretical and experimental study [42–44] reported that formic acid (HCOOH) could decompose to CO and H2O through dehydration path. This phenomenon has given us a new idea for the mechanism of RWGS reaction. Hence, HCOOH is regarded as an intermediate for RWGS reaction, and it is significant to choose how to proceed to decompose to CO. Therefore, the impact of composition and decomposition of HCOOH is studied by mechanism D and E. Scheme 1 displayed all of the proposed reaction mechanisms. We start with the analysis of five different reaction mechanisms on Mo6S8-TM clusters, (Fig. 1 , the structures of Mo6S8-Pt are almost same as the Mo6S8-Pd, so we only presented the structures of Mo6S8-Pd in Fig. 1, the structures of Mo6S8-Pt are showed in Fig. S1. In addition, the adsorption energies and the structures of the adsorption intermediates for five mechanisms on Mo6S8-Pd are presented in Table S2 and Fig. S2). Details on the elementary steps included in the five mechanisms are showed in Scheme 1. As shown in Fig. 1 and Scheme 1, all of the five different mechanisms are start with coadsorption of *CO2 and *H2 on the Mo6S8-TM. The adsorption structure of *CO2 on Mo6S8-Pd and Mo6S8-Pt are almost the same, the *CO2 is bent, while the *CO2 adsorbed on Mo6S8-Ag is nearly parallel to the surface and the C-O bond length is 1.18Å. And we found that which is nearly unchanged with respect to that in the gas phase CO2 molecule. Then, *H2 molecule is dissociated to two H* atoms via TS1. For the *H2 dissociation on Mo6S8-Pd, Mo6S8-Pt and Mo6S8-Ag, the reaction energy is 13.94, 16.63 and 13.76kcalmol−1 and the free energy barrier is calculated to be 24.83, 26.75 and 22.27kcalmol−1, respectively. At the TS1, the distance between two H* atom is 1.29, 1.43 and 1.50Å. To this end, we first focus our attention on the redox mechanism, and the potential energy surface for redox mechanism prompted by Mo6S8-TM clusters is described in Fig. 1(A). The Table 1 showed the reaction energies (ΔG) and activation barriers (Ea) of the elementary steps in five mechanisms for RWGS reaction on Mo6S8-TM clusters, and Table S3 displayed the energies of intermediates and transition states in five mechanisms for RWGS reaction on Mo6S8-TM clusters. 3.1.1 The redox mechanism In the case of the redox mechanism, *CO2 cleaves its C-O bond through transition state TS2 to form the CO* and O*. At the TS2, the distance of broken C-O bond of Mo6S8-Pd, Mo6S8-Pt and Mo6S8-Ag is 1.75, 1.72 and 2.07Å. For the *CO2 dissociation on Mo6S8-Pd, Mo6S8-Pt and Mo6S8-Ag, the reaction energy is 42.57, 47.56 and 59.39kcalmol−1 and the free energy barrier is calculated to be 53.98, 57.63 and 68.80kcalmol−1, respectively. The free energy barrier for *CO2 dissociation is higher than other steps, so this is its rate-determining step. As the reaction proceeds, the H* atom attacks the neighbor O* atom to forming OH*. The step of CO* +O* +2H* to CO*+OH*+H* is spontaneous, and it exothermic 50.83, 53.01 and 64.72kcalmol−1, respectively. Once the OH* forms, it contributes to reacts further with a H* atom to form H2O*. In the structure of TS4, the OH* locates on the top site of Mo atom and the distance of adsorbed H atom and O atom of OH* group is 1.57, 1.66 and 1.20Å. Our calculation shows that the formation of H2O* is exothermic 17.98, 19.83 and 19.52kcalmol−1 and the free energy barrier is 8.01, 13.31 and 29.55kcalmol−1, respectively. 3.1.2 The carboxyl mechanism As shown in Fig. 1, the structure of the second intermediate is coadsorption of CO2 * and two H* atoms, because of the H2 * molecule decomposes to two H* atoms. Then, two possible species (COOH* and HCOO*) will be formed, result of CO2 * hydrogenation by adsorbed H* atoms. We now consider the carboxyl (COOH*) mechanism, which the most desirable mechanism compared to the other four mechanisms. In the case of the carboxyl mechanism (see Fig. 1(B)), the H atom migrates from binding S atom to binding the O atom of CO2 via the TS2 to form the COOH*. This step is concerted (formation of a H-O bond while breaking S-H bond), and the TS2 has, indeed, a single imaginary frequency. For the formation of COOH* on Mo6S8-Pd, Mo6S8-Pt and Mo6S8-Ag, the reaction energy is 7.22, 3.26 and 12.91kcalmol−1 and the free energy barrier is calculated to be 9.73, 12.60 and 32.13kcalmol−1, respectively. Thus, it turns out to be very favorable to form the COOH*. Proceeding to the next step, the COOH* decompose to CO* and OH* species via TS3. In the structure of TS3, it breaks down the C-O bond, due to an increase in the distance between C and O from 1.34, 1.33Å and 1.34 to 1.93, 2.12 and 3.46Å, respectively. For the fourth intermediate (the formation of CO* and OH*), the OH* group binds with the substrate by a newly formed O-Mo bond, while CO* interacts with the substrate via a C-Mo bond. For Mo6S8-Pd, Mo6S8-Pt and Mo6S8-Ag, this step with a free energy barrier of 24.58, 26.38 and 36.89kcalmol−1, and an exothermicity of 15.48, 8.71 and 18.24kcalmol−1, separately. Owing to the free energy barrier of this step on Mo6S8-Ag is higher than that of neighboring steps, this step is their rate-determining step. However, the rate-determining step of Mo6S8-Pd and Mo6S8-Pt in carboxyl pathway is the step of CO2*+H2* to CO2*+2H*, namely the dissociation of H2. The step of H2O* molecule generated from OH* and H* species is no longer considered in this section, because it has discussed in the redox mechanism. 3.1.3 The formate mechanism We study the formate mechanism in this section, which is determined by the formation of HCOO* from the coadsorbed CO2 * and H*. The H atom approaches the C atom of CO2 molecule to build the H-C bond of HCOO via TS2. The vibrational frequencies of TS2 calculated to be −455.46, −422.17 and 490.17cm−1, separately. For the formation of HCOO* on Mo6S8-Pd, Mo6S8-Pt and Mo6S8-Ag, the reaction energy is −12.51, −24.49 and −11.18kcalmol−1 and the free energy barrier is calculated to be 27.54, 26.38 and 44.34kcalmol−1, respectively. Then, the HCOO* dissociates to CO* and OH* species through TS3, and the free energy barrier of TS3 is 47.68, 61.36 and 80.96kcalmol−1, respectively. From Fig. 1(C) and Table 1, it is clear that this step of Mo6S8-Pd, Mo6S8-Pt and Mo6S8-Ag is the rate-determining step. And the results show that the reaction of HCOO* decomposition of CO* and OH* may not proceed on Mo6S8-TM cluster. The description of the formation of H2O* molecule by OH* and H* species has showed in the redox mechanism. 3.1.4 The formic acid mechanism As shown in Fig. 1(D), with the proceeds of the formation of HCOO*, it very favorable approach the H* to hydrogenation to HCOOH* via TS3. The vibrational frequencies of TS3 on Mo6S8-Pd, Mo6S8-Pt and Mo6S8-Ag calculated to be −1156.69, −437.98 and 489.54cm−1, separately. In the structure of the fourth intermediate, the HCOOH* locates on the top site of TM atom through O atom, where the distance of the O-TM bond is 2.24, 2.14 and 2.23Å. For Mo6S8-Pd and Mo6S8-Pt, the reaction energy of HCOO* to HCOOH* is endothermic by 0.39 and 5.46kcalmol−1 and the free energy barrier is calculated to be 13.51 and 14.51kcalmol−1. However, the reaction energy of this step on Mo6S8-Ag is exothermic by 1.22kcalmol−1 and the free energy barrier is 37.93kcalmol−1. The result of our study turns out to be very favorable to form HCOOH* group on Mo6S8-TM. Li et al. [45] reported that the HCOOH can directly dissociate to CO and H2O through the investigation of the decomposition of the HCOOH both in vacuum and solution. Thus, cleave the C-H and C-O (hydroxyl oxygen) bonds of HCOOH* simultaneously will generate H2O* and CO*. This process through the TS4, and the free energy barrier of Mo6S8-Pd, Mo6S8-Pt and Mo6S8-Ag is 16.35, 17.01 and 41.88kcalmol−1. 3.1.5 The formyl mechanism The HCO could be invoked as the intermediate of HCOOH decomposition has studied by Mavrikakis et at. [46]. Therefore, with the proceeds of the formation of HCOOH*, it will dissociation into CHO* and OH* via TS4 in the formyl mechanism. This pathway is initiated by C-O breaking. The formed CHO* binds with the Mo6S8-TM via its C atom and O atom to form C-Mo bond and O-TM bond, where the bond length of C-Mo is 2.15, 2.15 and 2.15Å and the bond length of O-TM is 2.29, 2.20 and 2.31Å, separately. For Mo6S8-Pd, Mo6S8-Pt and Mo6S8-Ag, the process of HCOOH* decompose to CHO* is endothermic by 25.56, 27.87 and 31.09kcalmol−1 and the free energy barrier is 64.85, 66.80, and 79.16 31.09kcalmol−1. This step is their rate-determining step, and because the formation of CHO* is so expensive, we will not consider this possibility any further. Our study showed that RWGS reaction on Mo6S8-TM followed Path B by comparing the other four mechanisms. This is agreement with previous literatures [47]. For path A, C, D and E, the free energy barrier of their rate-determining step is very high, making them inefficient and not suitable for the catalytic cycle. Among the three catalysts clusters, the Mo6S8-Pd cluster shows the most favorable catalytic properties. 3.2 Comparison of the efficiency of catalysts using ESM The ESM has proven to be a fundamental and available tool. The Mo6S8-Pd has the highest TOF in carboxyl mechanism, 8.81×10−32 s−1, indicating that Mo6S8-Pd is the most favorable catalyst. 3.3 Mechanism of ethanol synthesis from CO and H2 on Mo6S8-Pd cluster The Mo6S8-Pd cluster shows the most favorable catalytic properties among the three catalysts clusters. Therefore, we also carried out DFT calculations to explore C2H5OH synthesis on the Mo6S8-Pd cluster. Extensive studies have been performed to identify the reaction mechanism of ethanol formation reaction [49–51], and on these basis, an optimal pathway will be identified. A total reaction mechanism for ethanol synthesis on the Mo6S8-Pd catalyst is described as Scheme 1. In order to performing these calculations, we constructed the catalytic cycle of ethanol synthesis prompted by Mo6S8-Pd cluster, as depicted in Fig. 3 . Fig. 3 described the geometries of the reaction intermediates and transition states (TS) involved in a for ethanol synthesis, and Table 3 showed the reaction energies (ΔG) and activation barriers (Ea) of the Elementary Steps for ethanol synthesis on Mo6S8-TM clusters. For ethanol synthesis, the mechanism starts from *CO hydrogenation to *CHO via TS1, this reaction is endothermic by 16.71kcalmol−1 and requires an activation barrier of 8.78kcalmol−1. In TS1, the C−H distance is decreased to 2.13Å from 2.56Å in CO+H. Then, *CHO can be hydrogenated to *CH2O via TS2 with the free energy barrier of 6.02kcalmol−1, this reaction is exothermic by 11.79kcalmol−1. In TS2, *CHO adsorbs at the Mo−Pd bridge site via C atom, and H adsorbs at the S atom of step edge. Proceeding to the next step, *CH2O hydrogenation to *CH3O is spontaneous, with the reaction energy is exothermic by 32.55kcalmol−1. It suggested that the *CH2O is very favorable hydrogenation to *CH3O. Next, the direct dissociation of *CH3O tends to produce *CH3 +O* via TS3. This reaction requires a free energy barrier of 38.08kcalmol−1, and it is slightly endothermic by 9.94kcalmol−1. In TS3, and the distance between C and O atoms is 2.02Å. As depicted in Fig. 3, it’s clear see that the direct dissociation of *CH3O is the rate-determining of ethanol synthesis. Afterwards, *CHO insertion into *CH3 first forms the intermediate IM, with adsorption energy of −25.93kcalmol−1. In IM, *CHO adsorbs at the Mo atom of step edge via C atom, and *CH3 adsorbs at the Pd atom of step edge via C atom with the C−C bond length of 4.39Å. Subsequently, IM further forms CH3CHO* is also spontaneous, and this reaction is exothermic by 31.45kcalmol−1. The step of *CHO insertion into *CH3 is a key step for ethanol synthesis precursor. Then, CH3CHO* hydrogenation to CH3CH2O* via TS4 is exothermic by 3.69kcalmol−1 with a free energy barrier of 20.54kcalmol−1. In TS4, CH3CHO* adsorbs at Mo−Pd bridge site via O atom, and H adsorbs at the S atom of step edge. As a result, CH3CH2O* followed by H hydrogenation to C2H5OH via TS5, indicating accomplishment of the ethanol synthesis. This reaction is exothermic by 18.02kcalmol−1 with a free energy barrier of 3.87kcalmol−1. In TS5, CH3CH2O adsorbs at Mo−Pd bridge site via O atom, and H adsorbs at the Mo-S bridge site, it has only one imaginary frequency, which is −771.94cm−1. Now, we brief summary of ethanol synthesis, Above DFT results show that the ethanol formation via *CO, *CHO, *CH2O, *CH3O, *CH3, CH3CHO*, CH3CH2O*, C2H5OH. The key step of these processes is *CHO insertion into *CH3, and the rate-determining is the *CH3O dissociate to *CH3 and O*. Interestingly, *CH2O hydrogenation to *CH3O is spontaneous, and the key step of one carbon grow to two carbons, namely *CHO insertion into *CH3 is also spontaneous, which is very beneficial to production practice. Thus, the Mo6S8-Pd cluster is favorable to ethanol synthesis. 4 Conclusions In the present study, the mechanism of the RWGS reaction and ethanol formation on Mo6S8-TM (TM=Pd, Pt, Ag) has been explored by DFT calculations with the aim to shed light on the reaction mechanism and catalytic activity. Five different reaction mechanisms relevant to the RWGS reaction have been considered, the key steps characterized by the following: the redox mechanism (CO2 * →CO* +O*), the carboxyl mechanism (CO2 * +H* →COOH*), the formate mechanism (CO2 * +H* →HCOO*), the formic acid mechanism (CO2 * +H2 * →HCOOH*), the formyl mechanism (CO2 * +H2 * →HCO* +OH*). Our results indicated that the most desirable mechanism is the carboxyl mechanism, while the other four mechanisms are considered as minor channels in the RWGS reaction cycle. Furthermore, the Mo6S8-Pd cluster shows the most favorable catalytic properties among the three catalysts clusters. Because the free energy barrier of the rate-determining step in carboxyl mechanism on Mo6S8-Pd is lower than others, and the carboxyl mechanism of Mo6S8-Pd has the highest TOF value (8.81×10−32s−1) compared to the TOFs of each reaction cycle. In addition, we also investigate the mechanism of ethanol synthesis starting with CO and H2 on the Mo6S8-Pd cluster. Calculations showed that the ethanol formation via *CO, *CHO, *CH2O, *CH3O is an optimal pathway for the overall CO conversion. Starting with *CH3O, *CH3 is formed by the decomposition of *CH3O. Then, *CHO insertion into *CH3 can form CH3CHO*, and further, CH3CHO* is successively hydrogenated to ethanol through CH3CH2O* intermediate. The results suggest that the Mo6S8-Pd cluster is beneficial to synthesis of ethanol. We hope that our results would stimulate experimental work to find Mo6S8-TM cluster. coredata.dc:description: We studied the mechanism of the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS; CO2 +H2 →CO+H2O) and ethanol formation catalyzed by Mo6S8-TM (TM=Pd, Pt, Ag) clusters using density-functional theory (DFT) calculations. We considered five different reaction pathways relevant to the RWGS reaction as follows: the redox mechanism, the carboxyl mechanism, the formate mechanism, the formic acid mechanism, and the formyl mechanism. We carried out the energetic span model (ESM) to explore the kinetic behavior of the five catalytic cycles. Reaction Gibbs free energies and activation energies for all pathways were determined for each transition metal. Our results indicated that the most desirable mechanism is the carboxyl mechanism. Among the three catalysts clusters, the Mo6S8-Pd cluster shows the most favorable catalytic properties. Then, we explored the ethanol synthesis starting with CO and H2 on the Mo6S8-Pd cluster. Calculations showed that the ethanol formation via *CHO, *CH2O, *CH3O, *CH3, CH3CHO*, CH3CH2O*, and the Mo6S8-Pd cluster is beneficial to synthesis of ethanol.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into the Mechanism of Reverse Water-gas Shift Reaction and Ethanol Formation Catalyzed by Mo6S8-TM Clusters
